2.text: Recently some friends of mine went to the Gordon Dam in Tasmania,

10.text: Then they dropped a basketball over the edge.

14.text: You can see that the basketball gets pushed around a bit by the breeze,

18.text: but it lands basically right below where it was dropped.

21.text: Now watch what happens when they drop another basketball,

24.text: but this time with a bit of backspin...

37.text: "This is Bret who just threw it."

40.text: I litterally just dropped it, with a bit of spin,

43.text: like I didn't even throw it, and it just took off, like we had no idea that was gonna do that.

48.text: And this is where I come in:

50.text: the basketball was subject to the Magnus effect,

52.text: which affects all rotating balls or cylinders as they fly through the air.

57.text: as the basketball picks up speed,

59.text: air on the front side of the ball is going in the same direction as its spin,

63.text: and therefore it gets dragged along with the ball and deflected back.

67.text: Air on the other side is moving opposite to the ball spin,

70.text: so the flow separates from the ball instead of getting deflected.

74.text: The net result is the ball pushes air one way,

76.text: so the air applies an equal force on the ball the other way.

80.text: And this is known as the Magnus effect,

82.text: named after Heinrich Gustav Magnus who described it in 1852.

87.text: Of course, Isaac Newton beat him to it by nearly two hundred years,

90.text: describing the flight of tennis balls at Cambridge College.

93.text: But, you know, he's got enough stuff named after him....

96.text: This effect is very important in sports like tennis, soccer and golf,

101.text: but could it have non-sport applications?

104.text: This is a sailboat. I know it doesn't look like a sailboat,

109.text: They are spinning cylinders called "Flettner rotors",

112.text: and they take the place of the sails.

115.text: They deflect crosswinds, using the Magnus effect, to propel the ship forwards.

120.text: And this is a plane with spinning cylinders instead of wings.

124.text: Using the Magnus effect, the cylinders actually generate more lift than traditional wings.

129.text: However they also generate way more drag, making them impractical.

133.text: This place only flew once, and then it crashed.

137.text: But the Magnus effect is making a comeback.

139.text: Here is an experimental rotor wing aircraft which generates all its lift from spinning cylinders.

145.text: And this is the E-Ship 1 which uses four spinning cylinders (that's four Flettner rotors)

150.text: to increase its efficiency and reduce the amount of diesel it burns.

155.text: So, in the future, the Magnus effect may help more than just basketballs fly.

165.text: Now the real reason my friends from "How Ridiculous" were at the dam

168.text: was to set the world record for the highest basket ever scored.

172.text: So go check out their channel and the video,

174.text: and subscribe to them for more epic trickshots.
